Expresses an idea using pictures and letters (Local)

Writing in Response to Literary or Informational Text â€“ Showing Understanding of Ideas in Text (RC:1)
In response to literary or informational text, students show understanding of plot /ideas/concepts byâ€¦
Representing understanding of text through pictures (pictures may include labels, which might only include beginning sounds and/or ending sounds) (Local)
Representing understanding of text through pictures, "words," "sentences," or some combination (Local)
Selecting information to set context/background (Local) EXAMPLE: When setting context include author and title
Selecting appropriate information to set context/background (Local) EXAMPLE: When setting context, include author, title, brief summary
Selecting ideas that support the development of a summary
Connecting what has been read (plot/ideas/concepts) to prior knowledge, which might include other texts (Local)
Selecting appropriate information to set context/background (State)
Writing an introduction that sets context/background (Local)
Summarizing ideas (Local)
Connecting what has been read (plot/ideas/concepts) to prior knowledge, which might include other texts (State)
Selecting appropriate information to set context/background (Local) EXAMPLE: When setting context, include introduction of a character to make sure the reader understands who the character is
Summarizing key ideas (Local)
Connecting what has been read (plot/ideas/concepts) to prior knowledge or other texts, by referring to relevant ideas (Local)
Selecting appropriate information to set context/background (Local)
Summarizing key ideas (Local)
Connecting what has been read (plot/ideas/concepts) to prior knowledge or other texts, by referring to relevant ideas (Local)
Selecting and summarizing key ideas to set context (State)
Connecting what has been read (plot/ideas/concepts) to prior knowledge, other texts, or the broader world of ideas, by referring to and explaining relevant ideas (State)
Selecting and summarizing key ideas to set context (Local)
Connecting what has been read (plot/ideas/concepts) to prior knowledge, other texts, or the broader world of ideas, by referring to and explaining relevant ideas (Local)
Selecting and summarizing key ideas to set context, appropriate to audience (State)
Connecting what has been read (plot/ideas/concepts) to prior knowledge, other texts, or the broader world of ideas, by referring to and explaining relevant ideas or themes (State)
Selecting and summarizing key ideas to set context, appropriate to audience (Local)

Connecting what has been read (plot/ideas/concepts) to prior knowledge, other texts, or the broader world of ideas, by referring to and explaining relevant ideas, themes, motifs, or archetypes (Local)
Explaining the visual components (e.g., charts, diagrams, artwork) of the text, when appropriate (Local)
Writing in Response to Literary or Informational Text â€“ Making Analytical Judgments about Text (RC:2)
In response to literary or informational text read aloud, students make and support analytical judgments about text byâ€¦
Using prior knowledge or reference to text to respond to a question using pictures (pictures may include labels, which might only include beginning sounds and/or ending sounds) (Local)
Using prior knowledge or references to text to respond to a question (evidence may take the form of pictures, words, sentences, or some combination) (Local)
Organizing ideas by using a beginning and an ending given a structure (Local)
Stating a focus (purpose), when responding to a given question (Local)
Using details or references to text to support a given focus (Note: support may include prior knowledge) (Local)
Organizing ideas by using a beginning, middle, and concluding statement/sentence given a structure (Local) EXAMPLES: template, frame, graphic organizer
Stating a focus (purpose), when responding to a given question (Local)
Making inferences about content, events, characters, or setting (Local)
Using details or references to text to support focus (Note: support may include prior knowledge) (Local)
Organizing ideas, using basic transition words (e.g., first, next, then, finally) and having a concluding statement (Local)
Stating and maintaining a focus (purpose) when responding to a given question (State)
Making inferences about content, events, characters, setting, or common themes (State) EXAMPLE (of theme): honesty isn't always easy
Using specific details and references to text to support focus (State)
Organizing ideas, using transition words/phrases and writing a conclusion (State)
Stating and maintaining a focus (purpose) when responding to a given a question (Local)
Making inferences about the content, events, characters, setting, or common themes (Local)
Using specific details and references to text or citations to support focus (Local)
Organizing ideas, using transition words/phrases and writing a conclusion that provides closure (Local)
Stating and maintaining a focus (purpose), a firm judgment, or point of view when responding to a given question (Local)

Making inferences about content, events, characters, setting, or common themes and the relationship(s) among them (Local) EXAMPLE: Identifying theme and then making links between content/events and theme
Using specific details and references to text or relevant citations to support focus or judgment (Local)
Organizing ideas, using transition words/phrases and writing a conclusion that provides closure (Local)
Stating and maintaining a focus (purpose), a firm judgment, or point of view when responding to a given question (State)

Organizing ideas, using transitional words/phrases and writing a conclusion that provides closure (State)

Making inferences about the relationship(s) among content, events, characters, setting, theme, or author's craft (Local) EXAMPLES: Making links to author's choice of words, style, bias, literary techniques, or point of view; making links to characteristics of literary forms or genres

Organizing ideas, using transitional words/phrases and drawing a conclusion by synthesizing information (e.g., demonstrate a connection to the broader world of ideas) (Local)
Narrative Writing â€“ Creating a Story Line and Applying Narrative Strategies (EW:1)
Students organize and relate a story line/plot/series of events byâ€¦

Using pictures to create an understandable story line, when given a structure (pictures may include labels) (Local) EXAMPLES: Draw a picture that tells a story about your family. Given a picture, a student is asked to tell a story about what's happening in the picture.
In written narratives, students organize and relate a story line/plot/series of events byâ€¦
Creating an understandable story line, when given a structure (may take form of words or pictures or some combination) (Local)

Creating a clear understandable story line, with a beginning, middle, and end, when given a structure (Local)

Creating a clear, understandable story line with a beginning, middle, and end (Local)
Using basic transition words, when appropriate

Establishing a problem and solution (State)

Creating a clear and coherent (logically consistent) story line

Applying Rules of Grammar, Usage, and Mechanics (C:1)
In independent writing, students demonstrate command of appropriate English conventions byâ€¦
Using phonemic awareness and letter knowledge to spell independently (using phonetic or temporary spelling) and logically representing consonant sounds (e.g., initial or final sounds) (Local)
Using phonemic awareness and letter knowledge to spell independently (using phonetic or temporary spelling when needed) (Local)
Correctly spelling many common words (e.g., had, can, including own first name) (Local)
Using capital letters for the beginning of sentences and names (Local)

Orally ordering ideas in a sequence or tell a familiar story
